Award.AwardTitle: Electrostatics and dielectric properties of bio-nano interface by spin-labeling EPR
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Tatyana Smirnova of the North Carolina State University to develop new Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) spectroscopy techniques for assessing the local electrostatics and dielectric properties of lipid-nano-structured hybrid materials. This research project focuses on designing new spectroscopic probes and developing experimental methods to investigate the influence of nanostructured support and confinement on properties of biological membranes and the membrane-protein interface. The research project is a vehicle for the training of graduate and undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds in highly interdisciplinary environment. Research activities are being integrated with education through designing of a suite of undergraduate teaching labs based on research and industrial applications of EPR spectroscopy. The proposed application-based suite of EPR laboratory exercises aims to improve STEM education and provide skills appropriate for the present day science and technology workforce.

New pH-sensitive EPR active probes and labels are being synthesized to enable measurements of proton concentration and local dielectric constant in heterogeneous nanoscale systems. The new methodology is being applied to profile local dielectric constant and proton gradients in phospholipid membranes and along membrane-protein interface. The extent to which nano-confinement of lipid membranes can alter the polarity, water and proton profiles within the phospholipid bilayer and at the protein-lipid interface and potentially disrupt the optimal conditions for the lipid-protein and protein-protein interactions is being investigated. The methodology being developed is expected to be widely applicable to an array of novel lipid-nanostructure hybrids that hold promise to open new analytical and technological applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Development of novel hybrid materials based on lipids and nanostructured surfaces promises to open many new opportunities for analytical and technological applications and paves the way towards biotechnology platforms that interface manmade nanostructures with self-assembled functional biosystems such as biological membranes, proteins, and their complexes.  At present, however, little is understood about the influence of a nanostructured support and nanoconfinement on electrostatic properties of the membrane-protein interface. The overall goal of this project is to develop new and expand the existing arsenal of experimental spectroscopic methods for assessing local electrostatics and dielectric properties of mesoscopic and nanoscale heterogeneous bio-inorganic systems.

In the course of this project we have developed new measurement methodology based on novel ionizable spectroscopic probes that could be positioned at well-defined locations in proteins, biological membranes or at the nanoparticle surfaces. The methodology allows for determination of local electrostatic potential and dielectric properties at the location of the probes. New probes were designed and synthesized for measurements at physiological and near physiological conditions. By using the new methodology, we have evaluated effects of silica support on the electrostatic environment of model biological membranes and membrane protein systems.

Research conducted with this NSF grant support advanced our understanding of properties of bio-nano interfaces while promoting STEM disciplines through teaching and hands-on training.  Graduate and undergraduate students, and research scolar received interdisciplinary training including state-of-the-art spectroscopic methods and experimental techniques that lead them to successful careers.  Support from NSF allowed for the graduate and undergraduate students, including students from traditionally underrepresent groups, to present results of this research at scientific conferences, thus, further advancing their professional development. Based on the results of this project a new teaching module has been developed and incorporated into graduate and undergraduate level classes.
